content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with five columns of data. The heading for row 1 is labeled “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is labeled “v sub P, of t, in meters per hour.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. v sub P, of t, is 0. Column 2. t is 0.3. v sub P, of t, is 55. Column 3. t is 1.7. v sub P, of t, is negative 29. Column 4. t is 2.8. v sub P, of t, is 55. Column 5. t is 4. v sub P, of t, is 48. " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(meters per hour)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>55</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>29</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>55</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>48</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The velocity of a particle, <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, moving along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is given by the differentiable function <math alttext="v sub P " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="v sub P, of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in meters per hour and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. Selected values of <math alttext="v sub P, of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. Particle <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at the origin at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. a) Justify why there must be at least one time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0.3 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 2.8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.3</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, at which <math alttext="v sub P, prime, of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acceleration of particle <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, equals <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> meters per hour per hour.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with five columns of data. The heading for row 1 is labeled “t, in hours,” and the heading for row 2 is labeled “v sub P, of t, in meters per hour.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. v sub P, of t, is 0. Column 2. t is 0.3. v sub P, of t, is 55. Column 3. t is 1.7. v sub P, of t, is negative 29. Column 4. t is 2.8. v sub P, of t, is 55. Column 5. t is 4. v sub P, of t, is 48. " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2.8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(meters per hour)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>55</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>29</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>55</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>48</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The velocity of a particle, <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, moving along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is given by the differentiable function <math alttext="v sub P " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="v sub P, of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in meters per hour and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in hours. Selected values of <math alttext="v sub P, of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. Particle <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at the origin at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. a) Justify why there must be at least one time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0.3 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 2.8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.3</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>2.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, at which <math alttext="v sub P, prime, of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acceleration of particle <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, equals <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> meters per hour per hour.

b) Use a trapezoidal sum with the three subintervals <math alttext="open bracket, 0 comma 0.3, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="open bracket, 0.3 comma 1.7, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>⁢</mo><mn>1.7</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="open bracket, 1.7 comma 2.8, close bracket" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mn>1.7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2.8</mn><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to approximate the value of <math alttext="the integral from, 0 to 2.8, of v sub P, of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2.8</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>.

c) A second particle, <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, also moves along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis so that its velocity for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="v sub Q, of t, equals, 45 times the square root of t, end root, times the cosine of open parenthesis, 0.063 times t squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn><msqrt><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msqrt><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.063</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"></mspace><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> meters per hour. Find the time interval during which the velocity of particle <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at least <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> meters per hour. Find the distance traveled by particle <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> during the interval when the velocity of particle <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at least <math alttext="60" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> meters per hour.

d) At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, particle <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at position <math alttext="x equals negative 90" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>90</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using the result from part (b) and the function <math alttext="v sub Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> from part (c), approximate the distance between particles <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 2.8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
